channel.title: Nature Communications
channel.description:
Nature Communications is an open access, multidisciplinary journal dedicated to publishing high-quality research in all areas of the biological, health, physical, chemical and Earth sciences. Papers published by the journal aim to represent important advances of significance to specialists within each field.

We are committed to providing an efficient service for both authors and readers. Our team of independent editors make rapid and fair publication decisions. Prompt dissemination of accepted papers to a wide readership and beyond is achieved through a programme of continuous online publication.

item.title: Towards terahertz nanomechanics
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 29 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63561-5

The authors report suspended Lamb-wave resonators using sub-100 nm ultrathin lithium niobate, achieving resonant frequencies of nearly 220 GHz-doubling prior records and holding exciting prospects for terahertz nanomechanics.
item.dc:title: Towards terahertz nanomechanics
item.dc:creator: Jiacheng Xie
Weifeng Wu
Mohan Shen
Patrick Fay
Hong X. Tang

item.title: Spatiotemporal dynamics of moiré excitons in van der Waals heterostructures
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 29 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64285-2

Here, the authors develop a predictive, material-specific many-body model for moiré heterostructures of transition metal dichalcogenides that tracks exciton dynamics across time, space, and momentum, fully accounting for the moiré potential and the complex non-parabolic exciton band structure.
item.dc:title: Spatiotemporal dynamics of moiré excitons in van der Waals heterostructures
item.dc:creator: Giuseppe Meneghini
Samuel Brem
Ermin Malic

item.title: Critical fluctuations and noise spectra in two-dimensional Fe<sub>3</sub>GeTe<sub>2</sub> magnets
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 29 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63578-w

The critical behaviour of phase transitions encodes information about the nature of the phase transition, however, extracting critical exponents associated with the correlation length and relaxation time is challenging. Here, taking the well-studied van der Waals magnet, Fe3GeTe2, Li, Ding, Wang, and coauthors use NV-centre based magnetometry to study critical fluctuations.
item.dc:title: Critical fluctuations and noise spectra in two-dimensional Fe<sub>3</sub>GeTe<sub>2</sub> magnets
item.dc:creator: Yuxin Li
Zhe Ding
Chen Wang
Haoyu Sun
Zhousheng Chen
Pengfei Wang
Ya Wang
Ming Gong
Hualing Zeng
Fazhan Shi
Jiangfeng Du
